natural problem: Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office?
natural solution: The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
shows  "fact members / fact (members - 4) = 5040"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
shows  "fact members / fact (members - 4) = 5040"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the number of ways to choose 4 people out of 10. The final answer is 5040.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members :: nat and officers :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
and h1 : "officers = 4"
and h2 : "officers \<le> members"
shows  "fact members div fact (members - officers) = 5040"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat and officers :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
and h1 : "officers = 4"
and h2 : "officers \<le> members"
shows  "fact members div fact (members - officers) = 5040"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a group of 10 members, in how many ways can you select 4 officers, assuming that any member can be an officer? The final answer is 5040.

a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "fact 10 = 3628800"
shows  "fact 10 div (fact (10 - 4)) = 5040"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the value of the factorial of 10 divided by the factorial of 6. The result is 5040.

theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
shows  "fact members / fact (members - 4) = 5040"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
shows  "fact members / fact (members - 4) = 5040"
 proof-

a_3.informal problem: Calculate the number of ways to select 4 members from a group of 10. The final answer is 5040.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pick :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. pick n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "pick 10 4 = 5040"
shows  "pick 10 4 = 5040"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes pick :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. pick n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "pick 10 4 = 5040"
shows  "pick 10 4 = 5040"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: The binomial coefficient, often read as "n choose k", is defined as the number of ways to choose k elements from a set of n elements. It is computed as the factorial of n divided by the product of the factorial of k and the factorial of (n - k). If "10 choose 4" equals 5040, confirm that "10 choose 4" equals 5040.

fixes members :: nat

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members :: nat and positions :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
and h1 : "positions = 4"
and h2 : "individual members can hold at most one office"
shows  "(fact members) div (fact (members - positions)) = 5040"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 10 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, treasurer, and morale officer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 5,\!040
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 10 members, the secretary can be any of the 9 remaining members, the treasurer can be any of the remaining 8 members, and the morale officer can be any of the remaining 7 members.
 There are $10\times 9\times 8\times7=\boxed{5,\!040}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat and positions :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 10"
and h1 : "positions = 4"
and h2 : "individual members can hold at most one office"
shows  "(fact members) div (fact (members - positions)) = 5040"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a club with 10 members, if each member can hold at most one office, how many ways can 4 offices be filled? The final answer is 5040.
